title: How to Decorate Cookies with Stencils

methods.name: Setting up the Cookie and Stencil

steps.headline: Ice your cookie with an even layer of royal icing, if desired.
steps.description: You can always add a stencil right over a bare cookie, but setting down a base layer of icing often looks better. Fill a piping bag with royal icing and outline the entire cookie before filling it in with the icing. The royal icing will spread out and harden so that the surface is smooth and perfect. Look for royal icing and piping bags at your local craft or big box store. Using regular buttercream icing instead of royal icing won’t give you a smooth, hard surface for the stenciling.

steps.headline: Let the icing dry overnight to ensure it’s hard.
steps.description: It’s important for the icing to be completely dry before placing a stencil on top of it, otherwise the stencil will leave indentations. After you’ve iced all of the cookies, let them sit overnight to be sure the icing is hard when you go to stencil them the next day. Leave the cookies uncovered overnight to avoid messing up the icing.

steps.headline: Place the cookie on a piece of parchment paper.
steps.description: Rip off a piece of parchment paper to cover your work surface, such as a kitchen counter or table. Place the cookie on the center of the parchment paper which will collect any icing spills.

steps.headline: Pick out a stencil that covers the entire cookie.
steps.description: It’s best to use a simple stencil the first time you stencil the cookies so they’re less likely to get messed up. Pick out a stencil without super fine lines and with easy shapes to make filling in the areas easier. Make sure the stencil lies flat on the cookie and covers its entire surface with room to spare on each side. Look for stencils at your local big box store, craft store, or online. Pick out a stencil that's labeled as food-safe.

steps.headline: Use magnets or a stencil frame to hold the stencil in place over the cookie.
steps.description: Purchase a stencil frame that uses magnets to hold the frame in place so your hands are free. If you don’t want to purchase a stencil frame, stack a couple small, round magnets on top of one another and place them around the cookie, putting the stencil in between them to keep it taut and in place. Stencil frames can be found online and are adjustable to fit any size cookie. For example, place 4 round magnets around the cookie, put the stencil on top of the magnets, and then add another layer of magnets on top of the 4 magnets to keep the stencil in place.

steps.headline: Create a stiff consistency of icing to spread over the stencil.
steps.description: The icing should be loose enough to spread over the cookie evenly while still being thick so it doesn’t run under the stencil. Try adding 1  tsp (4.9 ml) of water per 1 cup (240 ml) of royal icing, mixing them together thoroughly. Since royal icing is already super stiff, adding a little bit of water will help make it easier to spread. Test the icing by dipping a knife into it—if the icing should stick to the knife without falling off of it.

steps.headline: Use an offset spatula to spread the icing over the stencil’s openings.
steps.description: Dip the spatula into the icing and begin spreading it onto the cookie. Brush the icing on carefully in small amounts, spreading it over all of the crevices in an even layer. It's best to just use one color of icing over the stencil for the best results. If you're trying to apply 2 or more different colors of icing over the cookie stencil, you'll need to be very careful about where you spread each color. Use a smaller tool to spread each color over the specific stencil openings, if possible.

steps.headline: Smooth out the layer of icing several times to get rid of any peaks.
steps.description: Use the length of the offset spatula to smooth over the entire cookie. Go over it several times in different directions to get rid of any peaks or scrape marks, forming a flat layer of icing. Smooth the icing out so it doesn’t stand taller than the stencil, otherwise it’ll form peaks when you take off the stencil.

steps.headline: Lift the stencil up quickly and carefully to remove it.
steps.description: Grasp the edges of the stencil and lift it straight up to avoid smudging the icing. Keep a finger or two on the cookie to keep it from moving when you remove the stencil quickly. Lifting the stencil off at an angle is bad because it could smear your icing.

steps.headline: Clean and dry the stencil before using it on another cookie.
steps.description: If you don’t clean the stencil, the icing from the previous cookie could get on your new cookie and ruin the pattern. Wipe down the stencil with a damp paper towel to get rid of excess icing and dry it with a clean paper towel or rag.

steps.headline: Use a can of color mist food spray to decorate the cookie.
steps.description: Purchase a can of color mist food color spray from a grocery store or online. These cans come in many different colors and cover the stencil in an even layer of spray, leaving behind your desired pattern. Instead of a can of food color spray, you could use an airbrush to apply the food color evenly.

steps.headline: Hold the spray 3 in (7.6 cm) away from the cookie to apply a light layer of color.
steps.description: Shake the can of color spray well before applying it. Holding it away from the cookie will help ensure a light layer is applied and the color doesn’t run or become splotchy. Move the spray over the entire cookie until the color is applied evenly. If you’re using an airbrush, put it on low speed and pull the trigger lightly to apply a soft coat of color. Using a light layer of color also helps ensure the spray doesn’t leak under the stencil.

steps.headline: Apply additional light layers until you reach your desired shade.
steps.description: After the first light layer, check to see if you’re satisfied with the color. If you’d like it a little darker or more vibrant, apply another light layer just like you did the first, holding the can of food color spray at least 3 in (7.6 cm) away from the cookie as you spray.

steps.headline: Lift up the stencil carefully and swap it out for another one, if desired.
steps.description: Lift the stencil up carefully, removing the stencil frame or magnets first. Pick the stencil straight up and set another one down on top of the cookie if you’d like. Food color sprays can be applied on top of one another, creating lots of different colors on your cookie. Wipe the stencil down with a damp paper towel after you use it to make sure it doesn’t ruin the next cookie.
